segments.text: And that was a decision which I didn't have to, you might say, go into a separate discussion with myself, because I had been involved in it, on the thing.

It was perfectly clear to me that the development of a graduate education program here at Woods Hole Oceanographic, particularly in connection with MIT, the way we had this getting that started, that that was an extraordinarily worthwhile thing to do for the, should we say, for the welfare of the world.
No decision.
In other words, you don't make decisions at that point.
The pattern is perfectly clear.
And when you begin to make contact with MIT, what was MIT's reaction?
You've been cooperating with MIT for a series of years now in terms of teaching.
The responsibility, in a sense, for making those contacts was not really mine.
It had already been done.
The major person up there for getting things started, of course, was Frank Press, as you know, is now the science advisor to the president.
But I had also worked on the ICO days, had worked a little with Jerry Wiesner, who was the president, the boss of, I'd also worked briefly with Stratton.
So I knew MIT well enough to know that they're one of the few universities in which, if you had an objective that was worthwhile, that MIT could somehow or other find a way to do it.
And I must say, that's a rather unique university in that sense.
Was your first assignment dean then to begin to draw departments here at Woods Hole?
K.O.
Emery had already done that, too.
And this, really, the technical aspects of moving in as dean were extraordinarily simple, because so much state work had been done already.
The main objective was to, you might say, define the objective as the program.
And the objectives of the program really were that we would
regard Woods Hole as a community of scientists.
And the only difference between graduate students and, quote, members of the faculty is that they're beginning scientists, so to speak.
So that we tried to set it up, and had fair success at it, at avoiding the rather detailed and complicated curriculum that is so common in most graduate schools.
In other words, part of my objective was to hold down the organization, you might say, and to maintain the concept of its being a place for a young scientist to learn science.
Now, as an outsider, Woods Hole had not really ever been known much as a teaching institution.
It was primarily a research institution.
Why do you suppose Woods Hole began to move into graduate studies?
No, that's not true.
They...
Over the years, we've got the figures there.
There have been a large number of people doing their doctorate work here at Woods Hole.
But it would be done, someone from Chicago or from Yale or Harvard or wherever would be coming down, and we would make provisions for them, and they could work with one of our staff people.
So that in essence, we had been in the business all along.
We hadn't been in the formal business

of being able to tell a youngster, come down to Woods Hole and become a part of the scientific community and select the particular area you want to work in, and we'll make sure you can get a degree at the end.
Before that, that decision had been made by other universities, you see.
So it was simply a matter of a shift that we could, in effect, admit the students and select the students.
Rather than someone deciding with whom he would like to work and making overtures and this sort of thing.
When time comes for student recruitment, how do you go about it?
Send out the usual brochures, and the recruitment progress has been very good.
I've forgotten what it is, about 10 times larger than the ones we can admit.
We set an upper limit, which we've now reached.
And that is that the total number of students registered in one time should not exceed 80.
And we're sticking very closely to that.
And I might say we reached that level within two years, I remember.
That's being highly selective.
That's being highly selective.
Let's say about a 10 to 1 ratio.
Now, I know that your role as an administrator with fellow scientists would probably limit the amount of direction you could give, since it's sort of a community of equals.
But did you have any series of goals as an administrator that you should like to carry out down here?
No, except to... Let me put it this way, that assuming the general goal,
of creating the atmosphere for young scientists to learn science and the thing.
And with sort of the subset on that, that you try to avoid the excessive organization so that all students take X, Y, Z courses.
And they have to do it in a certain time and so on.
And try to model the thing so that it fits best both their backgrounds and their current interests.
they come in from widely different backgrounds.
Biologists, physicists, chemists, mathematicians, etc., etc.

So that the formalities of the thing, we again could do very easily because each of the departments here could set up its own sort of committee on the thing and could set up, they'd operate on an admissions committee.
We had to have
established joint committees with MIT, which again turned out to be very easy because MIT has as many rules as regulations as the ordinary university does.
But they also have a most remarkable knack of being able to work within those rules.
So essentially, I would say that the graduate school developed as a community of scholars.
basis, and that it wouldn't have been possible with any other combination that I know of, except possibly the University of Chicago.
We could have done it there.

Chicago also has that extraordinary flexibility, which I might say, having been at state universities for quite some time, too, it would be much more difficult than a state university, simply because of the organizational sort of rigidity sometimes that you encounter.
No, I had a relatively few problems.

One, there were a terrible number of small details, and if you want to know why I could succeed in that, because I know they'd have taken care of the administrative details and the like, it was because of Jake Pearson.
They finally got him up to
the position of assistant dean.
Before that, he was always assistant to the dean.
But Jake Pearson was remarkable.
Let me put it this way.
I came into a situation in which we already had the enthusiastic support of the important people.
By important, I mean scientifically important at MIT.
We already had enough people at Woods Hole Oceanographic
who would be interested in having some graduate students around.
And we already had K.O.
Emery, who had done quite a bit of six months to a year, something like that.
He'd begun to formulate the way some of the seminars and courses might be run on the thing.
And we had this remarkable man, Jake Pearson,
could not only grasp the concepts and assist in developing the concepts, but he could recognize that if you had a student at a given point, he had to somehow or other register properly with MIT.
He had to do it here, too.
He had to make sure that the tuition was taken care of, all those details, so that I had none of those problems.
except to make occasional decisions if there was a little bit of misunderstanding, things like that.
Extraordinarily simple job.
Was there any difficulty in encouraging research scientists, fundamentally research scientists, to accept teaching duties?
Oh, yes.
That would follow.
Difficulty in the sense that if...
If we had tried to stipulate to oceanographer X that you take on a course, we would have been a hell of a mess.
But we had enough people who would do it and say, well, yes, I'll try it for a year.
And then once they realized the joy of having some good graduate students paying attention to them, then they began to offer to do it.

But I'm sure that if we'd tried to follow more of a government laboratory type of operation where we would have taken and outlined all the staff members and said, well, now these guys will teach this course, and these guys will teach this course, and these guys will teach this course, I think it would have been a fiasco.
But it was within a couple of years.
The ones who had, some of the people who had originally said, the hell with it, don't ask me to do a thing with that.
They're on the point where they were at least taking in students and would say finally, well, these students want me to give a seminar on this.
And so I'd give a seminar.
Well, what's the difference between a good seminar and a course?
Seminar's better.
No, it was extraordinarily easy here.
So the transition then was quite smooth?
Yes.
Did the institution grow in terms of staff with any rapidity once you began to bring in students?
No, I think you'll find from the statistics that it's been pretty much level as far as that's concerned.
There's been a various number
quite a percentage.
I can't give you a percentage because I've been away for four years.
A fair percentage of our best people now are very happy to associate with graduate students.
And many of them will also contribute very directly to teaching.
Were there any accomplishments which you'd like to single out as dean that you were particularly proud of?
No, that would be a little hard to define.
The accomplishments are, of course, ones which depended not so much upon my operations as a dean as upon the fulfillment of the objectives that had already been expressed.
In other words, the number of applicants rose rapidly the first couple of years, reached a level that we could bring in the
the students so that we would head for this top level of 80 students maximum on the thing.
And we're giving, I think that amounts to 15 or so degrees a year.
And I would say the existence of the graduate school on an operating level is the chief of the objectives.
As far as I'm concerned, that's the accomplishment.

And I'm not being unduly modest when I say that my role in it was primarily that of just defining a few of the general ways in which it would operate, and then relying upon the fact that you had a bunch of damn bright, able people who would, if you had good graduate students, would recognize the real virtue of having young scientists learn their science.
And if you're interested in the history of science, I think you'll find a beginning recognition that the advancement of knowledge really depends in large part upon two roles of graduate students.
One is the work that they do, and the other is the role they have in changing their professor.
Essays on that are beginning to appear in public, I might say.
That's one of the things that, well, there's a, let's go back, there's a little bit of history on this that had to do with it.
I'd also been very closely associated with Detlef Barak, who was the, who ended up being the president of Rockefeller Institute and was responsible for changing it to Rockefeller University.
And his reasons for doing that

and I'd had many long discussions with him on that, was that many of the scientists in Rockefeller University were finding life rather dull, and it was showing up a little in the work that they were doing.
And so that and I agreed, and I wasn't so advised to him on anything like that, that this concept that if you had young scientists develop,
for the future, there are two real positive contributions.
One was the work they did, and the other was the stimulating effect that they have upon the people they're working with.
So that was in large part the definition that Ted Bronk had in creating the university out of the Rockefeller Institute.
And I had that background.
And in a sense, you'll see there's quite a bit of similarity between the two places.
Woods Hole Oceanographic, which was primarily a research institution, and Rockefeller Institute, which had been primarily a research institution.
And the same concepts that led to make that into the university also applied to the Woods Hole Oceanographic.
So I had more of an educational background in this whole thing.
And we also agreed thoroughly upon this concept that the community scholar's idea is the proper way to run a graduate school.
To hell with red tape.
If you have a bright student, somehow or other you make sure he can get his degree.
Get him out.
Get him out for the benefit of the public.
Now, when time comes to replace
yourself as dean.
Do you go through another search committee?
Do you try to bring somebody in again from outside?
Well, in this particular case, we're a very favorable position.
We had Bob Morris already here.
The answer is no, we didn't have to.
Because if you have someone who's been a notable scientist, been a dean at a university, and had been himself
assistant secretary of the Navy, and then had been president of the university.
And here he was sitting there.
You don't need to go on a search committee.
He got the outstanding candidate sitting right there.
Other than that, well, sure, there was the formality of a search committee.
Now, had he been here, though, when you had first come here, is it?
No.
I didn't think so.
No, he came in.
He's been here about two years, I think.
And, of course, he followed the work very closely and we're on good terms.
Now, the next series of questions I have are sort of personal questions that don't feel off balance.
If you had to list in your scientific career what you considered your major accomplishment, what would you list?
That would be a toughie.
The major accomplishment, scientifically, really, is something which has now outgrown me, should we say, and that is the development of the whole concept of ion movement.
Because at the time when I was a graduate student, ions didn't move back and forth across cell membranes except in certain, like potassium.
But the active movement of sodium, things like that, the development of the concept of the ability of cell membranes to move things back and forth,
I was very much part of it at that time.
Now then, I also made a decision, as I say, at about age 55, that that whole field was going very well indeed.
There were some very good youngsters coming along.
They were going to develop it.
And meanwhile, things had been happening.
Following the war, as you know, there was this development of the concept that there should be a federal support of science.
And I had also, something I forgot to mention earlier, I had also been mixed up early in the development of the Office of Naval Research Operation.
I was on, I think, their first advisory committee in biology on that.
So that when the legislation
relating to the Science Foundation began to get worked up.
I got involved in that, too, because I felt it had to be done and should involve some of the conceptual attitudes that the ONR had as well on the thing.
And I got actively involved in some of the legislative proceedings for a very odd sort of reason.
The first bill that was written
head for the National Science Foundation, a division of medical sciences with a subdivision of biology.
And being a biologist, of course, that threw me into a big flat.
I had to make certain that any legislation that went through would recognize that medicine was really an applied branch of biology.
As one devoted to Pressful, I couldn't stand seeing this legislation which served the Division of Medical Sciences and Subdivision of Biology.
Very odd.
Which gave rise to some extraordinarily interesting discussions with the deans of medical schools.
I bet it did.
I need to ask you some questions about ONR.
I didn't realize you were there when it was first organized.
How did the concept of ONR sort of emerge in terms of supportive science?
This is something which I have tried to get someone to give me the complete history, and I can't.
I can't answer that.
There's something about the structure of the Navy that allowed them to, once they established something, and I don't know who did this, and you put it under an admiral,
and you have a good captain in charge of it, and then he in turn can go out and get a good civilian to operate it, you can go ahead and be as innovative as you want to.
And who put in the original ideas, I don't know.
And I wish you would find out.
I don't have any idea.
I know Revelle was there, but I don't know where the idea of ONR came from.
I don't either.
And...
If I were you, if you ever get into Washington, look up a man named Chuck Schilling.
I think it's S-C-H. And Chuck Schilling, Bob Abel knows him well.
And Bob might know something about it.
But I really put that
something to look into in the future if you really want to follow the development of federal support of science.
Chuck Schilling was the captain in charge when I got involved with LNR.
It had been going for, I've forgotten, several years.
There's a moment I can't remember the date.
It was the late 40s.
I became involved.
How did you get involved in UNR?
I'm not quite sure.
Most of these questions you're asking about involvement, I'm sure you know that the
No matter how much organization you have, things are still personal associations on that.
And I have a feeling it was because...
I can't give names, but there were a couple of the Navy people in the old days of...
some of the congressional committees on the formation of the National Science Foundation, who became involved also with ONR and the personal association with them on that.
That's the answer.
Well, I think that's the way the world operates.
Oh, yes.
The world still operates on the Cousin Principle, really.
But fortunately, it's not entirely that.
In other words, it's possible to get into the circuit.
But difficult sometimes.
Yeah.
Difficult if you have to go through formal application procedures.
It's getting easier, of course.
I'm very pleased that it's possible for him to get a little outside of the Cousin principle.
Were there any particular accomplishments in, may I use the word, bureaucratic service?
I really don't mean that at all.
I mean in terms of committee advisory service, of which you're particularly proud.
Well, the Office of Naval Research had already devised a system of having an advisory group.
And so at the time that I was in the National Science Foundation, a very nice character named Alan was beginning to develop the National Institutes of Health system on the thing.
And we worked up a more extended philosophy of peer review committees.
And that I was proud of for a while, and now I'm disappointed in it, because the peer review committees are more and more getting the idea that they run the programs.
And the original concept we had, both in the ONR and when I was working with Allen and the NIH, was that the peer review groups would be advisory.
And the program manager was the one who really had to make the decisions.
on the basis of the recommendations of the peer review system.
And the reasoning there is very simple, and that is that if the program goes bad, all you have to do is fire the program director.
Whereas if he is in a position where you can say that all he's doing is following the rules of the peer review group, then how do you fire him, you know?
And you can't fire the peer review committee.
So I'm distressed at the fact that the peer review system has become so institutionalized and formalized that they now act as though they are the ones who run programs.
I love the concept of having someone responsible for a program, not necessarily so you can fire him, but so that you know who's really responsible for doing it.
Is there anything you'd like to add to the tape?
No, except to give you the warm approval of what you're trying to do.
And if you're interested in the history of how oceanography is developed, I hope you are dragging up the concept that oceanography really developed, not from
not people who were trained as oceanographers, but people who were devoted to study the oceans.
And, of course, here at Woods Hole, it was great.
You're doing this in a very good way.
But make a note sometime that if you would be interested in the discussions that went on,
to formulate, well, to do three things.
One is to establish what's so oceanographic.
The other is to convert scripts from really a biological station into oceanography.
And the third one was to goose up the University of Washington.
There is a collection of the correspondence and handwritten committee notes and everything else of Frank Willey.
which I managed to save by a series of accidents, they're over in the MBL library.

And that's something that if you want to really follow up on the sorts of discussions that went on by those characters at that time when they came up with this marvelous idea and they'd already sold Rockefeller Foundation to get some money for all these things.
It's well worthwhile, so keep a note on that.

If you ever get out of the, you might say, the Audible field, and someone wants to really look into the discussions that went on at that time, this was a National Academy of Sciences committee, and the discussions are terrific.
And we were very fortunate in that we have a couple of file drawers of handwritten, mostly handwritten notes by the chairman of that committee, Frank Lilley.
